This pub stands in the shadow of Manchester Town Hall. The rapid expansion of the city and the ambitions of its civic leaders led to the creation of a municipal palace of unrivalled splendour. Completed in 1877, this civic palace was designed by Alfred Waterhouse, also responsible for several other buildings in the city. Its internal mosaic design incorporates a pattern of bees, symbolic of Manchester‚Äôs industry, which is also found on the city‚Äôs coat of arms.

The text reads: This Wetherspoon pub takes its name from the leading 19th century architect Alfred Waterhouse, who designed the grandiose Town Hall building opposite here.

Waterhouse had already designed Manchester Assizes and Strangeways Gaol before winning the design contest for a new town hall, in 1868. The triangular building, with nearly 1,000 rooms, is recognised as his masterpiece. It was eight years in the making and was described as ‚Äúa municipal place‚Äù by the city‚Äôs Radical MP John Bright, whose statue is one of the many sculptures it now contains.

Design motifs on the mosaic floors include cotton flowers, the basis of the city‚Äôs prosperity, and bees. The bees, which also appear on the city‚Äôs coat of arms, symbolise Manchester‚Äôs industrious workers. The 280 feet high clock tower houses 23 bells. The eight-ton hour bell is nicknamed ‚ÄòBig Abel‚Äô after Alderman Abel Hayward, who opened the building. It is inscribed with the line: ‚ÄúRing out the false, ring in the true‚Äù, from Tennyson‚Äôs poem In Memoriam.

Waterhouse also designed London‚Äôs Natural History Museum, as well as Manchester‚Äôs Owens College. His use of terracotta and brick in educational buildings is said to be the origin of the term ‚Äòred-brick‚Äô, a term for universities which were originally municipal colleges.

The text reads: Stepping Back into History
Architectural history beneath your feet.
The staircase exposed during the renovation of this building dates from the Georgian period.
It takes us back over two hundred years, providing a vivid link with the past, and indicating the original cellular layout of the Georgian structure.

Review Text:
Service was pretty quick here, and the food was good - exactly as expected from any Wetherspoons.
The big downside to this location was the atmosphere. Around 5pm on a Monday, and it was unbelievably noisy with a few tables of people drinking and shouting. This isn't really the fault of Wetherspoons, although some things could be done to mitigate it. The tables are spread throughout several smaller rooms, and packed in very tightly. There isn't much to dampen the sound, so a couple of noisy tables in one room was enough to make it so we couldn't hear well enough to hold a conversation across our table.
Fewer tables per room, and maybe some curtains or something to absorb some sound, would make it slightly more bearable. But based on this experience, I wouldn't return to this branch.

The Lamb and Flag pub in Leeds, West Yorkshire, is a true gem among local establishments. From the moment you step through the doors, you are greeted with a warm and inviting atmosphere. The traditional yet charming interior creates a cozy ambiance, perfect for unwinding after a long day.

The pub's selection of ales and beers is impressive, catering to both connoisseurs and casual drinkers alike. Their staff is friendly and knowledgeable, always willing to recommend a new brew or discuss the latest offerings on tap.

The text reads: This Wetherspoon pub takes its name from the leading 19th century architect Alfred Waterhouse, who designed the grandiose Town Hall building opposite here.

Waterhouse had already designed Manchester Assizes and Strangeways Gaol before winning the design contest for a new town hall, in 1868. The triangular building, with nearly 1,000 rooms, is recognised as his masterpiece. It was eight years in the making and was described as ‚Äúa municipal place‚Äù by the city‚Äôs Radical MP John Bright, whose statue is one of the many sculptures it now contains.

Design motifs on the mosaic floors include cotton flowers, the basis of the city‚Äôs prosperity, and bees. The bees, which also appear on the city‚Äôs coat of arms, symbolise Manchester‚Äôs industrious workers. The 280 feet high clock tower houses 23 bells. The eight-ton hour bell is nicknamed ‚ÄòBig Abel‚Äô after Alderman Abel Hayward, who opened the building. One of the best Wetherspoons in the city. Lots of room. Service can be slow due to size of the bar. Not great kids as too busy. But good beer, good atmosphere, food is what you expect in that it does a job. It‚Äôs an alright place that might be too busy for some.

The only fault was that they didn't keep up to the clearing and that place was littered with glasses and crockery. Not enough staff most likely as they seemed to work hard.

A good breakfast. Stayed at a local hotel and didn't fancy the extortionate cost to upgrade to breakfast included as we knew there were numerous eateries locally. We left our hotel up the road and happened upon this place. It is what it is, a pub with decent grub. We couldn't use the app to order and had been informed when ordering at the bar there's a 30 minute wait for food which we understood as the place was packed even at 11am. When the food arrived it tasted great and was very good value. A perfect place to start our day visiting the markets. The customers were in good spirits and the place was very nice, the layout is a little splintered with rooms here there and everywhere.

Went in here on Tuesday, primarily to escape the torrential rain, but what a pleasant place to socialise. We had a couple of hours and sampled the excellent cask ales at excellent prices. Lots of little rooms to choose from and free coffee top ups if required.
Nice ale, nice price, lots of room, lacks atmosphere.

Love the look and layout of this place. Its decor and many rooms give it an overall feel that's more like a house than a pub. Smart, but cosy at the same time, and it has HUGE very posh loos. :) Service is fast and friendly even at busy times (which appear to be all the time). Great value for food and drink and good selection of beers and wines. Clientele a very broad mix, with plenty of professionals popping in at lunch time and after work, mixed in with shoppers and regulars. Very good location for everything, being close to most city centre landmarks, attractions and public transport (the St. Peter's Square Metrolink stop is right outside).

My favourite pub in Manchester. A Georgian terraced property close to the side of Manchester Town Hall. In a previous life I believe it was used as offices for Solicitors. Has multiple rooms of various sizes, so needs a walk around to locate the perfect sized table for your party!  Been there dozens of times. Great beer & food. The place is desperate for a makeover. Really beginning to look tatty lately. Needs a bit of investment. Needs a makeover and some fresh menus which are not grubby and food stained. Aside from that its a civilised venue with good prices. I love the fact there is no background music so you can talk to people!

Nice place for a quick pint after work. Very friendly and competent staff. A bit dirty tables times. Quite good selection of beers and ciders. I'll definitely return here during my next visit to Manchester!

If you want a quick cheap pint in town when you're maybe waiting to meet a friend or waiting for your tram then pop in here. The decor could do with an update but for a cheap ale I found it was just what I needed. Good selection of ales and as if it wasn't cheap enough low and behold it's even cheaper on a Monday. Can't go wrong.
Interesting many roomed Spoons with some good ales.

Staff are friendly and efficient. Always busy but there's secret rooms everywhere! Really nice bathrooms too which makes or breaks a pub for me.

Great bar, little chilly in the winter if you sit up nearer the door. Friendly staff and excellent choice of beer. Little pricey for this end of town (hence 4 not 5 star) but hipster with pretty young crowd so charging full market prices
